Pre-Game Insights: Argentina and Colombia expressed safety worries ahead of Sunday night's Copa America final, days after Uruguay's Darwin Núñez and a handful of his teammates went into the stands amid a brawl following a semifinal loss to Colombia.
Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said through an interpreter, speaking in a news conference Saturday before his team goes for a record 16th Copa America title against Colombia.
Colombia midfielder Juan Quintero expressed concern about the incident and hoped it would not happen during the final match.
Argentina goalkeeper Emiliano Martínez called for the tournament to reinforce security for the final.
CONMEBOL, South American soccer's governing body, condemned the violence in a news release the day after Wednesday's match at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina.

Both Argentina and Colombia are known for their passionate fanbases and will meet for the 44th time. More than 65,000 people are expected to attend the game, and asking prices for resale tickets have ranged from a couple thousand dollars to upward of $10,000.
Scaloni noted that his family will be in attendance and urged fans and others to respect their rivals.
